a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:55): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-device-apis/2010Jun/0333.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:55): bravo DougT

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:56): "I do not want to build or design an API that embeds policy information in it.  From a developers pov, i have never seen such an API nor would want to use one."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:57): relates to http://www.w3.org/TR/dap-privacy-reqs/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:58): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-device-apis/2010Jun/0335.html is a good read, too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:58): reads
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:59): hmm, http://www.w3.org/TR/dap-privacy-reqs/ is a Note, but uses RFC 2119 terms
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:00): and I realize now it's not a requirements list in the normal "use case and requirements" sense at all
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:00): instead, it is stating implementation conformance requirements
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ah, yeah (about that being a good read)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:02): there should be a FAQ we can point to about that particular question
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (11:03): http://www.opera.com/portal/geo/ hmm none in africa... oh wait actually one in egypt
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:04): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: privacy violation.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:05): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: huh? does Opera publish the location on that map when someone uses geolocation in Opera on another Web page?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:06): and this scholarly paper that people keep citing - http://escholarship.org/uc/item/0rp834wf - "Privacy Issues of the W3C Geolocation API"
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (11:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: only if you go to that page
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (11:07): The Link??ping office is in Bor?•s
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): "Privacy Issues of the W3C Geolocation API" is published through http://escholarship.org/about_escholarship.html -

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): "eScholarship provides a suite of open access, scholarly publishing services and research tools that enable departments, research units, publishing programs, and individual scholars associated with the University of California to have direct control over the creation and dissemination of the full range of their scholarship"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): "direct control"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): "Publications benefit from manuscript and peer-review management systems"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): ...but don't _require_ any actual peer-review

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:10): "So you get the appearance of having published your paper in an actual scholarly journal without having gone through any of the annoying and time-wasty peer review that such journals require."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:11): (the last quote is a paraphrase)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:16): the DAP reqs look to me like they want some kind of reverse DRM
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:16): (reverse in the sense of an individual applying DRM against a corporation)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:23): "Because retention, secondary use, and sharing are largely out of the control of the APIs, it's not entirely clear that it makes sense to have any API requirements about these aspects." indeed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:27): replace "retention, secondary use, and sharing" with the words "most or all of what this document attempts to cover"

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:59): Hmm, how does the geolocation thing know where I am? It seems to be accurate to within about 100m, when I'm just connecting from a laptop (no GPS device) to an ADSL line (which I didn't think were known that precisely)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:00): Maybe I told Google where I am at some point in the past and it's remembered
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:00): Is there some way to find out how it's making its decision?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:01): at one point (when connecting by cable modem) the location Google told Firefox was freakishli accurate for my office
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:01): but then later the precision regressed and Google started reporting the official center point of Helsinki
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (12:03): Chrome uses various location providers, including wifi scans

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:03): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, if you're referring to Opera's geolocation implementation, I believe it uses wi-fi based triangulation and Google's service to map that to a location
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:07): is surprised that would work on Linux
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:07): why wouldn't it work on linux?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:08): I wouldn't have thought there was a sufficiently standardised way of handling wifi on Linux
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (12:12): there are some libraries
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:17): I guess I'm just surprised when anything works immediately and straightforwardly on Linux
